Message.Title: Poor...stupid Sybil!
Message.Msg: Emphasis on the word poor!!!

I doubled my position at 228 and got out of ALL of the OOM options before earnings. I'm in great shape to ride this as long as possible. Between that move and the ride last year from 240 to 180, I remain ahead on AMZN. I've only been investing my own money in the market for about 3.5 years now, so I am absolutely still learning. But, I've more than doubled every year and am on track to do the same. I've found that the markets are not too difficult to beat for those that truly master abductive reasoning. The algos still cannot compete with that because it requires assessing the impact of emerging trends on competitive strategy and value capture. I will win here and big and funds accumulating now will be sued. An average joe knows what is really going on with AMZN's expansion and tax related moves. Those managing hundreds of millions or billions are are either negligent or choosing to ignore it to play games and try to squeeze out the last shorts... Those who play the game too long will lose big too, whether they make a little more first or not. It will get ugly for them, whether it be from yet another massive blow to trust (and thus huge redemptions) or whether it come from shareholder lawsuits. As I said, mock me now all you want. It will be clear in time and I will happily ride it out.

Topic.Title: The only thing good for shorts today is . . .

Message.Msg: which has sort been happening on the move violating below 240 now, violate then jam higher.

NASDAQ: I ran into the same confidence on NFLX, GMCR, CMG and LULU. Fortunately, some of the LT longs listened to me on GMCR BEFORE Einhorn published his short thesis and the stock tanked. I don't want anyone to get crushed, including you. Understand that long only funds cannot reverse and go short like you. They have a fiduciary obligation to shareholders and a material change to the Amazon consumer value proposition is in sight at this point. As I've said and will continue to say, if it was advantageous for AMZN to go bricks and mortar, it could have/would have done it sooner. Those long only funds cannot profit from a stock's drop. All they can do is try to anchor other funds and retail investors on an artificially high price (behavorial investing) and let it go from there. The issue is that any institutional longs buying at this point expose would be negligent IMHO... Most shorts/puts will be overly aggressive near term and get chewed up. I will be patient and make a killing when the longs have chewed up all the overly greedy retail shorts (on that Sybil is correct).

one thing about AMZN to GMCR, NFLX..etc: it has much more influence, support, and power in the economy of it's importance. I don't think you factor that in. Just look at the amount of daily articles and support in it: none of those other matter compared to AMZN: AMZN is a behemoth that well supported always. Comparing it to LULU: a sportswear maker? big mistake.

Betting against AMZN is like betting on the end of our civilization. AMZN represents a very big portion of global economy. If you're betting that our civilization will end soon, you should be shorting SPY, QQQ, and DIA. That is a lot safer than shorting AMZN.

I'm honestly not sure I follow your logic. Actually, there's a reason almost all MOMOs are in the consumer discretionary sector these days. They prey upon mass pyschology. They also leverage the financial media hype cycle. The challenge of course, is that when it reverses, it hit hard (see Facebook, which IMHO will be more valuable than AMZN long term because of its ease increasing returns to scale -- true network effects -- global scale, global currency hedge, especially when it turns on social commerce...). AMZN will actually be facing a LOT of negative PR soon enough. It did leverage DOJ in the anti-trust play against AAPL, when in reality in eBooks, it was AMZN that should have been investigated. Apple will bring it to trial and discovery will, in all likelihood, turn up some ugly internal docs, just as it did for GOOG in the ORCL trial. Who knows, it may even turn up some emails on the MSFA strategy designed to inhibit competition from etailers now that AMZN no longer can benefit from the subsidy. When AMZN's true strategy and motivations become clear, it will have a PR debacle on its hands. But, it will take awhile for all this to play out. In the meanwhile, the fast money boys will churn overly aggressive and greedy shorts and wipe them out. But, I'll be here and we'll compare notes in 12 months...

Topic.Title: Courage to hold here as Calif and PA start sales tax

Message.Msg: not to mention filling up your car with more bucks and foregoing that extra buy. I know I know: never matters espcially to the guys running the printing press: which is the biggest reason for the constant run in AMZN.

"All been front running QE " not sure of this, because when QE is delivered, it's via POMO daily market operations, it's "dosed" to the banks on a daily basis over a period of time that the Fed announces in the amount it announces: so you only frontrun it so much. Right now you have "Twist" and the jawbone of more QE unlimited: which is kind of nut at $100 oil when the last was near $68. Oil prices crushed demand in 2008 and the Fed risks that into creating these supported prices , that are in some cases, getting gigantic. But if it comes, it will mostly likely take the market mechanism compoletely out of market discovery over a period of time again.

The market has fully priced in QE. It doesn't need the actual flows to happen since its is just a few players playing pong anyway. The essential part is seeing the outflows that happened today. Cash is coming out and it will accelerate. The actual POMO operations will be necessary to keep some fraction of the market inflated. That fraction will not include AMZN...

your not understanding what I'm saying: it's not priced in if it comes because it will be delivered daily in increments to the market: what you are hoping is the market has gotton strong enough , and commodity have skied enough that you hear that the Fed will not do it next week at Jackson Hole. If it comes, the market will most likely go higher with it. When has QE not levitated the market ? espcially if the Fed blance sheett is expanded beyond $3 trillion. You don't get to frontrun what you dont' have yet.

I think you are wrong: if the market can levitate with the outflows here without expanding the balance sheet and just duratuon of Fed holdings, then, additional QE, especially unlimited could do wonders to further leviation. I think they are nuts to be considering it here but if they do, no blance sheet Fed expansion has failed in rising the stock market. And it's risen without expansion since last 2011 October when Twist started reinvesting matured proceed of bonds.

Message.Title: Big Guys Booming
Message.Msg: AMZN, AAPL, GOOG, PCLN all roaring in the past 2 weeks. Blow off may come this week, even tomorrow, so must prepare to hedge. AMZN is most interesting, because what is driving it is unknown.

Sure it can. Markets front run news all the time. How often does a stock selloff AFTER a great announcement? Think whatever you want. I'll putting my money on the line based upon my POV, not thinking naive thoughts. The rotation will kick into high gear once any actual QE is announced.

I wouldn't put PCLN with those, as it fell over 100 point just two weeks ago in AH: the others are near or at 52 week or alltime highs: with GOOG and AAPL having huge cash balances against the third and more sane multiples. AMZN's value is in a class by itself not seen since 2000, completely overlooking the up and downs to limited earnings and treating sales growth like they are earnings in themselves.
When have you ever seen QE balance sheet expansion not levitate the markets? you havn't . You are just picking the point where you think it won't work anymore. I think that's naive.
Question: what is the market "PEG ratio"? How has it moved over the past 3 years? How has it moved since June?
Every subsequent QE has been shorter lived. Now they've taken it to the limit...

their idea: that running stock prices up is creating the confidence to keep spending: paper asset inflation: except now it's more like paper asset bubble inflation at this point: they are the market maker in these QE periods It's not about the economic numbers: it's about what it does to the stock market, which they hope keeps inducing better economic numbers: for the top 1 % it's a boom for their wealth why real costs are getting more and more untenable for others. The Fed works for the banks, not improving the economy with this overt use of QE at this stage and it shows. The big question is what will kabash on them doing it? bond rejection ? oil prices? we'll have to see.

Every subsequent QE has been shorter lived. Now they've taken it to the limit... " I agree: in fact , I think their overmeddling is at the heart of the bubbles of the last decade: this one no different: it's gonna end badly by turning themselves into a hedge fund: but the market can be lifted with QE: especially when you a nutcase like Rosengen talk about an unlimited kind ahead. The've turned the Fed into a full blown managed hedge fund: beyond dangerous. But there's no limit to printing until something makes them stop doing it. They think it helps the economy here: most would disagree. Not bankers.

Message.Title: Very disheartened that Amazon is still maintaining this absurd share price.
Message.Msg: I met Jeff Bezos briefly last year and have never met a sadder sack of sheet in my life. He is very full of himself and grimaced as he reluctantly shook my hand in passing. I think my napsack was a turn off to him. Anyway, My girlfriend and I have ordered numerous things from the site and the overall quality has been dimishing with each subquential order. Netflicks offers a far superior product and the Kindle doesn't come close to the iPad. Would you like to be my friend?

Topic.Title: What will happen if their web site is down

Message.Msg: That is their life blood and the losses would be enormous. That would be a good way for a wanna be cyber terrorist to get noticed. Would really make a name for himself. It would have to be a man though, girls don't have the ingenuity or brain power to do something like that.

Message.Title: Put Debit Spread Today
Message.Msg: Bought a September 270 / 245 put debit spread when AMZN was $144 and change this afternoon. Paid about $18.25. Hoping it will be worth $25 in about four weeks . . .

Message.Title: Tomorrow is crucial!
Message.Msg: & critical

Gillis is the only analyst covering AMZN that has a clue. Your observation is what PJ and I were referring to last night. The TTM and Forward earnings multiples will have to skyrocket to maintain current levels if AMZN meets expectations... Who will be left below deck when the titanic sinks? Smart funds are getting off via the upper deck right now. It's going to get progressively harder to get out as it starts to take on water...
